title: Demographic and housing characteristics
text: 2020 Demographic Housing Characteristics file (DHC) table detailed, block-level information socioeconomic conditions. Census API tables Decennial Census, lack level detail DHC. tables lack spatial resolution. example, tables like Demographic Profile (DP) Congressional District (cd11X) provide data block level. tables lack demographic resolution. example table Redistricting Data (PL) contains many fewer cross-tabulations race housing situation. DHC provides fine-grained detail, can seen definition link : product include topics age, sex, race, Hispanic Latino origin, household type, family type, relationship householder, group quarters population, housing occupancy housing tenure. tables iterated race ethnicity. ambitious portfolio means DHC huge complex, 249 groups, sub-tables, hold total 9067 separate variables. used Census API create data table R captures information link just . variables provide compact way API present information, need assistance meaningful actual humans. glossary tables come .

title: Demographic and housing characteristics
text: glossary table explicitly lays connection row number Census API variable demographic meaning represents. example, single variable “H12B_010N”, might reports number rented households headed Black, non-Hispanic, householder. captures information race, ethnicity, home ownership, number households. glossary explains group H12B therefore need least 4 columns. report documents process follow create glossary table group DHC.

title: Demographic and housing characteristics
text: glossary group need enough columns represent detail captured rows. first step glossing group count many columns appear variables’ lists details. many detail columns needed DHC groups. groups need three fewer columns capture details, many need . Three different tables need six columns! ’ll use examples proceed. DHC groups need six columns capture details
code: DHC_VARIABLES |>     dplyr::summarize(         `Columns Present` = .data$Details |>             purrr::map_int(length) |>             max(),         .by = "Group"     ) |>     dplyr::count(         .data$`Columns Present`,         name = "Frequency"     ) |>     knitr::kable(         caption = "How many detail columns are needed by DHC groups."     ) hoist_group_details <- function(.glossary, .group, .fields){     .field_list <- .fields |>         seq_along() |>         rlang::set_names(.fields)     .glossary |>         dplyr::filter(.data$Group == .group) |>         tidyr::hoist(.col = "Details", !!!.field_list) }  GROUP_DETAILS <- DHC_VARIABLES |>     dplyr::summarize(         Concept = dplyr::first(.data$Concept),         Length = dplyr::n(),         Width = .data$Details |>             purrr::map_int(length) |>             max(),         .by = "Group"     ) |>     dplyr::mutate(         Variables = purrr::map2(             .data$Group, .data$Width,             \(.g, .c) {                 .tmp <- DHC_VARIABLES |>                     hoist_group_details(                         .g,                         LETTERS[1:.c]                     )                 if (nrow(.tmp) > 1) {                     .tmp <- dplyr::select(.tmp,                                           tidyselect::where(                                               \(.) dplyr::n_distinct(.) > 1                                           ))                 }                 dplyr::mutate(                     .tmp,                     dplyr::across(tidyselect::any_of(LETTERS[1:.c]),                                   \(.) dplyr::coalesce(., ""))                 )             }         )     ) EXAMPLE_GROUPS <- GROUP_DETAILS |>     dplyr::filter(         .data$Width == 6     ) |>     dplyr::select(         !tidyselect::any_of(c("Variables", "Width"))     )  knitr::kable(     EXAMPLE_GROUPS,     caption = "DHC groups that need six columns to capture their details" )

title: Demographic and housing characteristics

Glossed details group PCT2 Note use NA represent “possible value” state factor. ’m sure good choice. might better use explicit value like ““,””, “*“. make things consistent across factors Boolean fields, though.
code: PCT2 <- GROUP_DETAILS |>     dplyr::filter(         .data$Group == "PCT2"     ) |>     dplyr::pull(         "Variables"     ) |>     purrr::pluck(1)  knitr::kable(     PCT2,     caption = "The details of group PCT2" )

what: Glossaries that Explain the Census API's Decennial Group Tables
title: Glossaries that Explain the Census API's Decennial Group Tables
text: hercdectables data package contains glossaries US Census groups. glossary mapping variable names collection explicit values variables encode. example, variable Census database might report count number people one demographic group living one type housing primarily speaking one language. glossary group include columns demographic group, housing type, primary language. glossaries explain Census API’s Decennial group tables.
